column3: But there you have it! "A brother in Ireland who needs help----"

column2: I have on several occasions been to the Shakespeare country, approaching it from different directions, but each time I am set down at Leamington.
column3: I have on several occasions been to the Shakespeare country, approaching it from different directions, but each time I am set down at Leamington.

column2: Perhaps this is by some Act of Parliament--I really do not know; anyway, I have ceased to kick against the pricks and now meekly accept my fate.
column3: Perhaps this is by some Act of Parliament-I really do not know; anyway, I have ceased to kick against the pricks and now meekly accept my fate.

column2: Leamington seems largely under subjection to that triumvirate of despots--the Butler, the Coachman and the Gardener.
column3: Leamington seems largely under subjection to that triumvirate of despots-the Butler, the Coachman and the Gardener.

column2: You hear the jingle of keys, the flick of the whip and the rattle of the lawnmower; and a cold, secret fear takes possession of you--a sort of half-frenzied impulse to flee, before smug modernity takes you captive and whisks you off to play tiddledywinks or to dance the racquet.
column3: You hear the jingle of keys, the flick of the whip and the rattle of the lawnmower; and a cold, secret fear takes possession of you-a sort of half frenzied impulse to flee, before smug modernity takes you captive and whisks you off to play tiddledywinks or to dance the racquet.

column2: But the tram is at the door--the outside fare is a penny, inside it's two--and we are soon safe, for we have reached the point where the Leam and the Avon meet.
column3: But the tram is at the door-the outside fare is a penny, inside it's two-and we are soon safe, for we have reached the point where the Leam and the Avon meet.

column2: Warwick is worth our while.
column3: Warwick is worth our while.

column2: For here we see scenes such as Shakespeare saw, and our delight is in the things that his eyes beheld.
column3: For here we see scenes such as Shakespeare saw, and our delight is in the things that his eyes beheld.

column2: At the foot of Mill Street are the ruins of the old Gothic bridge that leads off to Banbury.
column3: At the foot of Mill Street are the ruins of the old Gothic bridge that leads off to Banbury.

column2: Oft have I ridden to Banbury Cross on my mother's foot, and when I saw that sign and pointing finger I felt like leaving all and flying thence.
column3: Oft have I ridden to Banbury Cross on my mother's foot, and when I saw that sign and pointing finger I felt like leaving all and flying thence.

column2: Just beyond the bridge, settled snugly in a forest of waving branches, we see storied old Warwick Castle, with Caesar's Tower lifting itself from the mass of green.
column3: Just beyond the bridge, settled snugly in a forest of waving branches, we see storied old Warwick Castle, with Caesar's Tower lifting itself from the mass of green.

column2: All about are quaint old houses and shops, with red-tiled roofs, and little windows, with diamond panes, hung on hinges, where maidens fair have looked down on brave men in coats of mail.
column3: All about are quaint old houses and shops, with red tiled roofs, and little windows, with diamond panes, hung on hinges, where maidens fair have looked down on brave men in coats of mail.

column2: These narrow, stony streets have rung with the clang and echo of hurrying hoofs; the tramp of Royalist and Parliamentarian, horse and foot, drum and banner; the stir of princely visits, of mail-coach, market, assize and kingly court. Colbrand, armed with giant club; Sir Guy; Richard Neville, kingmaker, and his barbaric train, all trod these streets, watered their horses in this river, camped on yonder bank, or huddled in this castle yard.
column3: These narrow, stony streets have rung with the clang and echo of hurrying hoofs; the tramp of Royalist and Parliamentarian, horse and foot, drum and banner; the stir of princely visits, of mail coach, market, assize and kingly court. Colbrand, armed with giant club; Sir Guy; Richard Neville, kingmaker, and his barbaric train, all trod these streets, watered their horses in this river, camped on yonder bank, or huddled in this castle yard.

column2: And again they came back when Will Shakespeare, a youth from Stratford, eight miles away, came here and waved his magic wand.
column3: And again they came back when Will Shakespeare, a youth from Stratford, eight miles away, came here and waved his magic wand.

column2: Warwick Castle is probably in better condition now than it was in the Sixteenth Century.
column3: Warwick Castle is probably in better condition now than it was in the Sixteenth Century.

column2: But practically it is the same.
column3: But practically it is the same.

column2: It is the only castle in England where the portcullis is lowered at ten o'clock every night and raised in the morning (if the coast happens to be clear) to tap of drum.
column3: It is the only castle in England where the portcullis is lowered at ten o'clock every night and raised in the morning (if the coast happens to be clear) to tap of drum.

column2: It costs a shilling to visit the castle.
column3: It costs a shilling to visit the castle.

column2: A fine old soldier in spotless uniform, with waxed white moustache and dangling sword, conducts the visitors.
column3: A fine old soldier in spotless uniform, with waxed white moustache and dangling sword, conducts the visitors.

column2: He imparts full two shillings' worth of facts as we go, all with a fierce roll of r's, as becomes a man of war.
column3: He imparts full two shillings' worth of facts as we go, all with a fierce roll of r's, as becomes a man of war.

column2: The long line of battlements, the massive buttresses, the angular entrance cut through solid rock, crooked, abrupt, with places where fighting men can lie in ambush, all is as Shakespeare knew it.
column3: The long line of battlements, the massive buttresses, the angular entrance cut through solid rock, crooked, abrupt, with places where fighting men can lie in ambush, all is as Shakespeare knew it.

column2: There are the cedars of Lebanon, brought by Crusaders from the East, and the screaming peacocks in the paved courtway: and in the Great Hall are to be seen the sword and accouterments of the fabled Guy, the mace of the "Kingmaker," the helmet of Cromwell, and the armor of Lord Brooke, killed at Litchfield.
column3: There are the cedars of Lebanon, brought by Crusaders from the East, and the screaming peacocks in the paved courtway: and in the Great Hall are to be seen the sword and accouterments of the fabled Guy, the mace of the "Kingmaker," the helmet of Cromwell, and the armor of Lord Brooke, killed at Litchfield.

column2: And that Shakespeare saw these things there is no doubt.
column3: And that Shakespeare saw these things there is no doubt.

column2: But he saw them as a countryman who came on certain fete-days, and stared with open mouth.
column3: But he saw them as a countryman who came on certain fete days, and stared with open mouth.

column2: We know this, because he has covered all with the glamour of his rich, boyish imagination that failed to perceive the cruel mockery of such selfish pageantry.
column3: We know this, because he has covered all with the glamour of his rich, boyish imagination that failed to perceive the cruel mockery of such selfish pageantry.

column2: Had his view been from the inside he would not have made his kings noble nor his princes generous; for the stress of strife would have stilled his laughter, and from his brain the dazzling pictures would have fled.
column3: Had his view been from the inside he would not have made his kings noble nor his princes generous; for the stress of strife would have stilled his laughter, and from his brain the dazzling pictures would have fled.

column2: Yet his fancies serve us better than the facts.
column3: Yet his fancies serve us better than the facts.

column2: Shakespeare shows us many castles, but they are always different views of Warwick or Kenilworth.
column3: Shakespeare shows us many castles, but they are always different views of Warwick or Kenilworth.

column2: When he pictures Macbeth's castle he has Warwick in his inward eye:
column3: When he pictures Macbeth's castle he has Warwick in his inward eye:

column2: This castle hath a pleasant seat: the air Nimbly and sweetly recommends itself Unto our gentle senses. This guest of Summer, The temple-haunting martlet, does approve, By his loved mansionry, that the heaven's breath Smells wooingly here: no jutty, frieze, Buttress, nor coign of vantage, but this bird Hath made his pendent bed, and procreant cradle; Where they most breed and haunt, I have observed, The air is delicate.
column3: This castle hath a pleasant seat: the air Nimbly and sweetly recommends itself Unto our gentle senses. This guest of Summer, The temple haunting martlet, does approve, By his loved mansionry, that the heaven's breath Smells wooingly here: no jutty, frieze, Buttress, nor coign of vantage, but this bird Hath made his pendent bed, and procreant cradle; Where they most breed and haunt, I have observed, The air is delicate.

column2: Five miles from Warwick (ten, if you believe the cab-drivers) are the ruins of Kenilworth Castle.
column3: Five miles from Warwick (ten, if you believe the cab drivers) are the ruins of Kenilworth Castle.

column2: In Fifteen Hundred Seventy-five, when Shakespeare was eleven years of age, Queen Elizabeth came to Kenilworth.
column3: In Fifteen Hundred Seventy five, when Shakespeare was eleven years of age, Queen Elizabeth came to Kenilworth.

column2: Whether her ticket was by way of Leamington I do not know.

column3: But she remained from July Ninth to July Twenty seventh, and there were great doings 'most every day, to which the yeomanry were oft invited.

column2: John Shakespeare was a worthy citizen of Warwickshire, and it is very probable that he received an invitation, and that he drove over with Mary Arden, his wife, sitting on the front seat holding the baby, and all the other seven children sitting on the straw behind.

column2: It is eight miles from Warwick to Stratford by the direct road, but ten by the river.

column2: I have walked both routes and consider the latter the shorter.

column2: I should say to Ann first and His Honor second.

column2: Charlcote is as fair as a dream of Paradise.
column3: Charlcote is as fair as a dream of Paradise.

column2: In Charlcote Church is a memorial to Sir Thomas Lucy; and there is a glowing epitaph that quite upsets any of those taunting and defaming allusions in "The Merry Wives." At the foot of the monument is a line to the effect that the inscription thereon was written by the only one in possession of the facts, Sir Thomas himself.
column3: In Charlcote Church is a memorial to Sir Thomas Lucy; and there is a glowing epitaph that quite upsets any of those taunting and defaming allusions in "The Merry Wives." At the foot of the monument is a line to the effect that the inscription thereon was written by the only one in possession of the facts, Sir Thomas himself.

column2: Several epitaphs in the churchyard are worthy of space in your commonplace book, but the lines on the slab to John Gibbs and wife struck me as having the true ring:

column2: Farewell, proud, vain, false, treacherous world, We have seen enough of thee: We value not what thou canst say of we.
column3: Farewell, proud, vain, false, treacherous world, We have seen enough of thee: We value not what thou canst say of we.

column2: When the Charlcote Mansion was built, there was a housewarming, and Good Queen Bess (who was not so awful good) came in great state; so we see that she had various calling acquaintances in these parts.
column3: When the Charlcote Mansion was built, there was a housewarming, and Good Queen Bess (who was not so awful good) came in great state; so we see that she had various calling acquaintances in these parts.

column2: But we have no proof that she ever knew that any such person as W. Shakespeare lived. However, she came to Charlcote and dined on venison, and what a pity it is that she and Shakespeare did not meet in London afterward and talk it over!
